msDesc.head: HUGH OF ST CHER; S. XV (before 1466)

msItem.note: fol. iii blank; on the verso are titles in hands of s. xvi and xvii

msItem.author: HUGH OF ST CHER
msItem.title: Postills on Genesis-Ruth
msItem.rubric: Exposicio Hugonis de Vienna super primum prologum Genesis.
msItem.incipit: Principium uerborum tuorum. Veritas Deus pater immo et operum scriptum est
(Exod., fol. 84) Isa. xix. Erant v. ciuitates in terra ...; v. ciuitates v. libri Moysi sunt
(Levit., fol. 102v) Sicut in principio librorum aliarum facultatum
(Num., fol. 122v) Pentateucus liber unus est ab uno auctore editus
(Deut., fol. 140v) Est puer unus qui habet v. panes ...; Puer iste est Moyses qui dicitur puer
(Ios., fol. 166v) Sexto loco inter libros ueteris testamenti ponitur liber Iosue
(Iud., fol. 181) Post mortem Iosue Iob v...; Verba sunt Eliphat Temanites
(Ruth, fol. 198) Ecc. xi. Breuis in uolatilibus apis et tamen magnus exoritur fructus tocius ecclesie
msItem.explicit: et altiora disputare sicut Apostolus fecit. Deo gracias. Explicit liber Ruth.

supportDesc.collation: A singleton, 1–258; catchwords; the quires numbered at the end; also quire-signatures of the usual late medieval form, mostly cropped.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with fine pencil in 2 cols of 60 lines.

handDesc.handNote: Written in the elegant upright bookhand of the professional scribe Henry Mere, lemmata in larger script, its body occupying two lines of the gloss, with an intervening line for ascenders and descenders. At the foot of fol. 200v Mere has written ‘Item recepi pro istis septem quaternis xxiii s.’ M. B. Parkes, ‘A fifteenth-century scribe: Henry Mere’, BLR 6 (1961), 654–9; DHL, no. 101.

decoDesc.decoNote: Books open with handsome large initials, typical English professional work of the period: on fol. 1 9-line P with coloured foliage on a square gold ground, with 3-sided border; smaller initials in gold with white tracery on pink and blue grounds, sprays of green leaves and gold bezants in the margins (champes) on fols. 84, 102v, 122v, 140v, 166v, 181, 198. Blue initials flourished with red; red running heads on specially ruled lines, with blue paraphs; red underlining.

binding.p: s. xix, sewn on five bands. Fols. i-ii and 201–2 are paper binding-leaves.

origin.origPlace: England(?); written by a professional scribe Henry Mere

history.provenance: At the head of fol. iiiv is ‘Liber domus scolarium de Merton ex dono magistri Henrici Seuer sacre pagine professoris ac eiusdem domus custodis incathenatus ad communem usum sociorum in libraria studere uolencium anno Domini M. CCCC. lxvi’. For Henry Sever, warden 1455–71, see MS 6.
On the same leaf is ‘O. 5. 1. Art:’, s. xvii. Inside the front board is the College bookplate with ‘O. 5. 2’, canc. and replaced with ‘M. 3. 1 (CLI)’ in red. ‘1’ is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.
